ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class was excellent. I gained in-depth knowledge related to different topics on China.
Learned significantly about Chinese governance, hard power, soft power and notions on possible grand strategy. We also discussed issues on economy and civil liberties.
An overall knowledge about politics in China.
current research about China in several fields

Learned how to synthesize large amounts of readings, express myself concisely, and actively voice my thoughts in class. Content-wise, I learned about multiple view-points of China, from politics to economy to grand strategy.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Amazing professor. Professor Mattingly is incredibly knowledgable and a great leader of discussions. Readings were always very interesting. Sometimes, I wish the readings connected more to the overarching topic we were discussing that week, but overall a very good, diverse selection.

The strengths of this course include the variety of content covered, its grading scheme, and the instructor's collective approach to teaching. I encourage the instructor to maintain the general structure of this course as is. 

One way to potentially improve this course is to assign a foundational text to each section for reference. One example of this could be to assign a short introduction to the mechanics of China's Golden Projects during the week on surveillance. While the academic literature is great and should be included, including a descriptive piece each week might help improve in-class discussion.
Professor Mattingly is organized and gives very helpful feedback
It's hard to think of weaknesses! The weekly readings were all interesting and thought-provoking, and clearly very thoughtfully put together. By far the best class on China I've taken at Yale.

Professor Mattingly is bar none the best professor I've had at Yale. He makes every class incredibly engaging, and his understanding and flexibility took away so much stress throughout the semester. I'd so heavily recommend this class to anyone, not just for the material, but also to take a class with Professor Mattingly.

Strengths: Incredible Professor with high flexibility and genuine care for students learning experience. Case studies and readings were always relevant and discussed and pretty compelling. Workload was reasonable. 
Weaknesses: Seminar size became fairly large, but that turned out to be okay.

Strength: plan for each class is clear;
Weakness: the quality of some reading materials is not so good.
I really enjoyed this course. I thought its strengths were the quality of the discussions, the variety of the readings, and the professor. I did not find there to be any weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Professor Mattingly is phenomenal.
Definitely, it's a fantastic seminar if you're studying China.
Definitely. Everyone was very invested in the class and Prof. Mattingly really works to incorporate everyone's thoughts and put them in conversation with each other.
Absolutely. The material is super relevant and interesting, and Professor Mattingly is incredible. Highly recommend.
yes!
Yes, Prof. Mattingly creates an environment of free speech as well as being a great expert on everything China.
Yes, I would recommend students who want to study or are interested in Chinese politics.
I would definitely recommend this course -- Prof Mattingly is a great professor and really engaging.

This is an excellent course that has something for everything who is interested in China studies, from discussions of elite politics to foreign policy to hard power. I would absolutely recommend it, particularly for those who are prepared to do a significant amount of reading/prep for each session. It's worth it to put the time in!

Yes, especially if you've taken and enjoyed Rise of China. Taking a seminar with Professor Mattingly was a valuable experience -- you get more individual feedback and get to hear his informed takes on the topics on the syllabus. He is also just a super approachable and kind professor.

Yes! I got so much out of this class and Professor Mattingly is such a great professor who truly cares about his students. The small format of the class allowed for productive and nuanced discussion. I would highly recommend this class.
